results.title: Who's responsible?
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande and JW Newman Corp
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
I am the cause of my own effects. This is a difficult concept for many to accept; most people prefer to “blame” others or environment for what happens to them. Teenagers attending a PACE conference deal with the concept of responsibility. Their discussions highlight how ‘what happens to you is under your own control to a very great extent’ and that, by exercising your choice, you can ‘create the effect your want to have in your life’.

results.title: Self esteem
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande and Robert Sande Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”

Shows young people at a seminar discussing self-esteem including expectations of self, negative “self-talk” and child/parent relationships.

results.title: Putting yourself together
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Two teenagers and counsellor Daniel Whiteside take a close look at how to think your way past the put-downs or problems that often weaken your self-image. The give-and-take between the three, draws us into the film and challenges us all to start taking control of this part of our lives.

results.title: Kids, parents and pressures
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande, Robert Sande Productions and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Teenagers attending a PACE Seminar identify some of the everyday pressures and tensions that confront them. With the help of highly qualified instructors, they learn they are in control of their own attitudes and work out positive and effective ways of improving their attitudes and relieving pressures.

results.title: Wendy
results.creator_credit: Jan Sharp, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
Wendy has her pregnancy terminated by abortion and the film reveals some of her reactions, her boyfriend’s and those of her mother to this situation. The film concludes with Wendy emphasising the importance of communications in teenage relationships. Cinemaphotography by Dean Semler. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Kerry
results.creator_credit: Jan Sharp, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
Kerry is a fifteen year old girl who leaves home and lives with her boyfriend. She becomes pregnant and returns to her family. The film considers some of the effects that the pregnancy and the decision to keep the baby have on Kerry’s relationship with her family and her boyfriend.

results.title: Jenny
results.creator_credit: Jan Sharp, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
A film focusing on a teenage girl in a homosexual relationship. Jenny discusses her perception of the ‘gay’ scene, her relationship and how she feels other people perceive her life-style.

results.title: Disco
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
This film considers social and sexual expectations and attitudes of teenagers attending a disco. Their perceptions of male and female roles, the similarities and differences are portrayed through their behaviour, conversation and dress. Cinematography by Mike Edols.

results.title: Brad
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
Brad identifies himself as a homosexual. The film examines his reactions to homosexuality and the importance of relationships with other males. His mother expresses her feelings about Brad’s sexuality; he is shown in his employment and enjoying himself socially.
